transcript: This is a lecture in two parts.
Part one,
Figures of History.
The year is 1955.
In Singapore,
the young painter Chua Myat Thie has just completed what will later become one of his best-known works,
Epic Poem of Malaya.
Meanwhile,
a new constitution has just granted much of the city's largely immigrant population the right to vote for the first time.
While falling short of full self-governance,
the move marks the first tentative step taken by the people of the city.
Towards post-colonial nationhood.
While Singapore is today the name of the nation, widely recognised as the result of the struggle for independence that began in the 1950s,
Back in 1955,
the nation to which the anti-colonial struggle aspired went by a different name,
Malaya.
This much is revealed not only by the title of Trawamati's painting,
but also a detail in the image.
In the Hand of the Passionate Orator is a book with the title
Malayan History,
as inscribed in Chinese, on its cover.
In a reflection of the people's burgeoning national consciousness,

The painting by Chua Mya Thi depicts a group of Chinese students listening to an orator recite from a book on Malayan history. As part of the self-study movement that blossomed within the community at the time.
Indeed,
ever since, Singapore was established as a British anthropotrating port,
in the early 19th century.
The island city at the tip of the Malayan peninsula had been deeply embedded within the commercial,
political and intellectual networks of the Malay archipelago. And relied especially on the vast Malayan hinterland for its abundant natural resources.
Given this,
any vision of nationhood expressed at that time saw the future of the city as inextricably bound to that of the peninsula.
However,
the actual process through which Singapore gained its freedom from colonial rule was also much more chaotic than what was depicted by Chua Mya Thi in his paintings.
Despite the broad consensus on Singapore's union with Malaya,
the precise contours of the nation to come and the terms of the union were highly contested,
with movements and interest groups of all political orientations fighting for influence over the formation of the new nation-state.
Quite unlike Chuang Miati's painting of a people in stoic contemplation,
a more representative image of the era is of the masses taking their protests to the streets,
having been spurred by networks of progressive and radical activists into taking direct action against colonial rule.
And of all these networks,
nothing rattled the British more than the network of Communist Party affiliates that had infiltrated trade unions,
schools and other organisations across the city.
Once described by the British novelist Graham Greene as a mist that pervaded everything.

The Malayan Communist Party was a formidable and clandestine presence across the peninsula that had only grown in strength after the British declared war on the party and forced its operations underground.
Officially known as the Malayan Emergency,

this protracted war that lasted until 1960 was started as part of British efforts to safeguard their long-term interests. In a region where the demands for decolonisation could no longer be suppressed.
Seeing that there was no bigger threat to these interests than a Malaya under the spell of communism.
The colonial government made it its priority to ensure that the Communist Party would play no part in the post-colonial government that would follow.
But as they eventually found out,
in order to destroy a network so extensive and tenacious,
violence alone was not enough.
One also had to construct a space where the people's exit from the network could be secured.
Beginning in 1950,
large parts of the ethnic Chinese population that made up the primary base of the Communist Party were forcibly resettled into so-called new villages, or kampung barus,
where barbed-wired fences and armed guards restricted the ability of the villages to provide food and shelter to guerrilla insurgents.
But more than a security operation,
this experiment in pastoralising a population that had mostly been living in squatter settlements located around plantations and mines.
Was initially also conceived as part of a campaign to win their hearts and minds.
The idea was that by allowing them to enjoy the material comforts,
such as education and healthcare,
which came with living within the planned community,
the villagers would be convinced of the merits of social democracy over communism.
However,
the British strategy quickly unraveled,
as many villagers grew to resent their containment and surveillance over time.
With some even throwing their lot with the communists as a result.
Having failed to win their hearts and minds,
the colonial authorities soon realised that what the villagers actually thought or believed in was irrelevant,
as long as they acted in a manner that produced useful information.
From here on,
the counter-insurgency operations of the British took a communicative turn.
Instead of simply relying on propaganda pamphlets and radio broadcasts,
the authorities doled out increasingly generous monetary rewards in exchange for information,
while routinely rounding up the villagers to drop slips of paper into collection boxes,
where they could offer their information anonymously.
Significantly,
the British saw these practices as a rehearsal for a highly proceduralised form of democracy that they hoped the new villagers could model,
one where civic participation was reduced to a process of feedback through which a population and its administrators
adjusted their respective behaviours to reach a mutual accommodation of each other.
What started as an intelligence operation by way of mere data collection,
thus began to produce a kind of artificial intelligence,
in the sense of a technical system capable of constant adaptation by processing and acting on the information it received across an entire population.
So successful was the strategy,
that it was quickly steadied by administrators across the empire and beyond,
eventually even becoming a template for counterinsurgency operations against the Viet Cong during the Vietnam War.
the U.S. and South Vietnamese authorities,
following the advice of British military officers who had served in Malaya,
launched the Strategic Hamlets programme that aimed to isolate rural populations from the guerrilla fighters by forcibly relocating millions of peasants into fortified villages.
However,
the programme was abandoned the following year,
after failing to achieve its objectives.
Unlike the British experience in Malaya,
corruption within the South Vietnamese government and a lack of civilian cooperation had doomed the initiative from the very beginning.
In contrast,
a more direct and successful emulation of the British experiment in Malaya was implemented in Kenya in 1953,
where colonial administrators introduced a similar policy of villagisation.
After the outbreak of an armed revolt against colonial rule.
And just like in Malaya,

the process was, in part, a project to de-radicalise a population whose political inclinations were seen to threaten the emerging world of global markets, in which the British sought to retain the economic advantages it had accrued through colonialism.
Remarkably,
it was also within the Kenyan New Villages where the media theorist Marshall McLuhan later found his inspiration
for his famous concept of the global village.
A concept first explored in his 1962 book,
The Gutenberg Galaxy.
That is widely seen to have anticipated the development of the internet.
In this classic of media theory,
McLuhan repeatedly invokes Africa and Africans as part of his attempt to compare how literate and so-called primitive non-literate populations receive information.
Central to McLuhan's thesis is the idea that the advent of electronic new media in the 20th century allowed Western society to return to what he called the Africa within.
In reference to a much more sensuous mode of experiencing the world that had been displaced by the invention of the printed word.
A world connected through electronic new media would therefore feel much smaller and more intimate,
like the African village of McLuhan's imagination.
However,
as the architectural historian Ginger Nolan points out,
what is almost never discussed among media scholars is that. McLuhan's arguments were partly built upon theories of the so-called African mind
that were developed through colonial research conducted specifically in the Kenyan New villages.

Or that the colonial deployment of radio and film in Africa that so fascinated McLuhan was part of a strategic effort at transforming an agitated public sphere into a highly mediated site of information flows that could be easily integrated within the emerging global market economy.
To this end,
the global village is not merely a metaphor,
for our contemporary networked condition.
It is also a historical legacy of a colonial experiment that first emerged in the Malayan hinterland,
as part of a war. To keep a larger,
much more powerful network at bay.
One could even say that in turning towards the global village. At the height of the anti-colonial movement,
Theorists like McLuhan were, in fact, also turning away from the struggles that were taking place in actual villages across Asia and Africa.
Where villageization was often in itself, an act of violence.
So, to avoid the fate of being forcibly incorporated into what was shaping up to be a global chain of new villages,
many Malayan Chinese naturally decided to flee the peninsula altogether.
For most,
their destination was the separately administered port City of Singapore,
located across the causeway from Malaya.
However,
once there,
the new arrivals soon found themselves again faced with the prospect of resettlement,
with the launch of a massive slum clearance and rehousing campaign by the Colonial Urban Planning authority,
the Singapore Improvement Trust,
despite occurring at the same time as the construction of the new villages on the peninsula.
The campaign in Singapore was less concerned with tackling Communist infiltration than with managing the city's post-war population surge.
Indeed,
as suggested by the name of the organisation,
improvement rather than containment was the order of the day,
as squatters were targeted to be relocated into multi-storey,
modernist apartment blocks.
Unlike in the peninsula,
a series of crackdowns had reduced the Malayan Communist Party to a small and disorganised network of cadres by the early
1950s. In Singapore,
with little capacity to contact,
let alone mobilise, squatters living in settlements so hazardous and unnavigable to visiting officials that they were basically deemed ungovernable.
Compared to the horizontal displacement of squatters into villages in Malaya.
Here,
the vertical ascent of the displaced population was thus conceived. Not as a military operation against a highly organised insurgent force,
but as a civilising mission to lift the people from a state of anarchy into some semblance of social order.
But to the extent that slum clearance in Singapore was carried out by civilian authorities,
squatters refusing to be uprooted for all kinds of social
and economic reasons,
were able to put up a strong resistance that their Malayan counterparts could not,
and in so doing,
refute the myth that squatter communities were incapable of organising themselves.

Such efforts proved such a hindrance to the rehousing programme that most of the plans drawn up by the British remained unfinished. By the time the popularly elected People's Action Party had taken over power.
Armed with a strong mandate,
the new government began making even more ambitious plans to rehouse the population,
while introducing policies that reduced the costs of relocation.
Yet, despite these improvements,
the re-housing campaign continued to face a lingering but determined opposition well into the early
60s, All while the ruling party was dealing with an internal crisis after members of its more radical left-wing flank split from the party.
It was against this context
that the government soon took to identifying farmers and squatters resisting relocation as objects of instigation by pro-communist elements.
In the end,
it took an overnight security sweep,
that eliminated the staunchest opponents to the re-housing program for the government to prevail.
By the time Singapore entered the newly constituted nation-state of Malaysia in 1963,
The public housing program had become such a success that the city was even selected as the venue for the second Afro-Asian housing Congress.
Along with the accelerated construction of public housing,
a boom in public buildings designed by local architects soon followed.
With much of the the architecture.
Melding European modernism with distinctive regional elements in a celebration of the nascent Malaysian nation.
The nation,
it seemed,
had defeated the network.
But the celebrations would not last for very long.
tensions between the Singapore government and its federal counterpart in Kuala Lumpur began to reach a tipping point.
With the emergency now over and the communists likewise decimated. In Singapore,
the nation that was conjured into existence as a container to insulate the population from the networks of international communism lost its primary function,
in turn, allowing long-standing political rivalries and tensions within the country's multi-ethnic society to simmer to the surface.
As the situation escalated with the outbreak of race-based riots,
an exit from the federation was hastily negotiated for Singapore,
which resulted in its establishment as an independent city-state on August 9.
And so it was that Singapore found itself born as a nation without a narrative,
without a story it could tell itself about who it was.
The point could not have been put better across by the Foreign Minister, S.
Rajaratnam,
who months after the separation still insisted that the idea of a Singaporean national identity was ludicrous.
However,
the economic urgencies of the day demanded that existential questions be set aside.
As the country focused on recovering from the loss of the common market with Malaya,
while pushing on with its industrialisation drive.
a narrative finally emerged when the same Roger Ratnam delivered what is now known as his Global City Speech.
Borrowing the expression from the British historian Arnaud Toynbee,
The minister proclaimed to a room of journalists that Singapore was now a global city. That no longer worried about the loss of the Malayan hinterland.
For the world had become its hinterland.
As a global city,
Singapore,
according to the minister,
was becoming an important part of a chain of cities. Connected through the tentacles of technology,
allowing it to trade with any place in the world, and not just its immediate neighbours.
It's worth mentioning that back in the
1960s, Marshall McLuhan himself had already conceived of the global city in relation to the global village.
In a letter to his close colleague,
the British Urban Planner and United Nations technical advisor,
Jacqueline Tewit,
McLuhan spoke of the importance of creating a global city as a kind of centre for the village margins,
a concept that was likely influenced by Tewit's own work in India,
where she constructed village centres as sites of education to enfold villages into the emerging networks of global development.
Singapore of the
1970s was becoming one such centre for the global village.
The network was now part of its identity.
For sure,
the kinds of networks into which Singapore was embedding itself were categorically distinct from the communist networks so feared by the British colonial government and its post-colonial successes.
Nonetheless,
policy planners in Singapore were deeply aware of the tensions between the nation and the network.
As Roger Ratnam himself saw it,
It was the task of the government to create the necessary antibodies to give the national body
immunity against the many dangers posed by foreign capital.
This approach was most observable in the government's approach to urban planning,
which,
not unlike the strategies being pursued by much of the Third world,
emphasised central planning and hierarchical control.
However,
having studied numerous case studies across the world,
the authorities also recognised the sheer complexity of rebuilding the city for a mostly immigrant population coming from different parts of the world.
And bringing with them different customs and ways of life.
Such was the concern expressed by one policy researcher in a 1969 radio and television talk series that aimed to educate the public on the challenges of urban design.
Citing an experiment in public housing and urban renewal in Chicago,
that saw a newly built modern estate turn into a hotbed for poverty,
gang violence and drug-related crime.
He explained that the experiment failed because the residents,
who had mostly been relocated from slums,
brought with them their old habits,
old ideas,
old beliefs.
And their old way of life when they moved in.
His conclusion was that despite changing their physical environment,
the experiment failed to change the people themselves.
The housing development that was being referred to was not named,
But it's clear that he was speaking about the Cabrini-Green,
a predominantly African-American estate,
which is often held up by neoliberal think tanks. Today, as a cautionary tale of what happens when the state,
rather than the market,
decides on housing.
Indeed,
throughout the
1960s and 70s,
the growing decay of U.S. Cities haunted the policy imaginary in Singapore,
with planners and architects repeatedly invoking the ghetto,
referring to U.S. inner cities, populated mostly by African Americans, as a worst-case scenario.
Yet the question of how much the state should get involved to avert this fate was highly debated.
Meanwhile, in the US,
against the backdrop of the civil rights movement,
the political scientist Carl Deutsch was reflecting on how individuals become integrated into a community.
Having been exposed to cybernetic theory through Norbert Wiener when he was a professor at MIT,
Deutsch sought to apply what Wiener called the science of control and communications to entire political and social systems.
As a field that emerged during the
1940s, cybernetics attempted to connect computational logic to the structure of the brain.
With some of the first experiments funded by defence contracts supporting the war effort,
and further developed during the Cold War,
Rejecting the age-old distinction between man and machine,
The first generation of cybernetizens aspired to build machines capable not only of following commands,
but also adjusting their future behaviour by learning from past performances.
Believing that problems with a high degree of indeterminacy cannot be solved by writing better rules.
Cyberneticians sought instead to develop systems that could dynamically regulate themselves to achieve a desired outcome,
by cycling information through feedback loops.
The political theory that Carl Deutsch was developing in the
1960s was a continuation of these ideas,
except that he was applying them to the study of government and society.
Something that Wiener and other first-generation cyberneticians rejected on the basis that human psychology is so complex that the methods of cybernetics will only be useful.
Under very controlled settings.
One could think,
for instance,
of the military-controlled Malayan New villages,
where colonial administrators tried to change the behaviours of their subjects without having to win over their hearts and minds.
However,
for Deutsch and other second-generation cyberneticians,
their project was precisely about changing,
or one might say,
rewiring the mind,
by understanding how information loops through the minds of the observers and incorporates them into the system.
Being observed.
By this token,
politics, as Deutsch saw it, is less about ideology or power than about maintaining a network of communication channels for the transmission and reception of information.
In particular,
on the subject of racism,
Deutsch saw the issue not as a legacy of colonialism,
but as a problem of the arbitrary agglomeration of information into static identity categories.
Or, in other words,
a blockage of information flows.
That is,
if a particular group of people,
with a particular set of characteristics,
are observed to be behaving in a particular way,
over and over again.
These observations eventually produce race as a visual sign.
Accordingly,
the task of the government here is not any kind of economic redistribution,
in the name of levelling the racialised inequalities inherited from colonialism,
But the redistribution of signals,
in the event of a blockage,
so as to resume the smooth and continuous flow of information.
Deutsch's radical ideas were highly influential within theoretical circles of the time,
and were studied by his contemporaries, such as Marshall McLuhan himself.
However,
there was little opportunity for their real-world application. Amidst the prevailing social democratic norms of the
1960s and 70s,
or during the subsequent neoliberal counter-revolution,
beginning in the
That sought to replace the state with the market altogether.
But the day would eventually come for the ideas laid out by Deutsch to become reality.
Not least in a country where the integration of the population and its government within an endless feedback loop has been long in the making.
the Singapore government launched the Smart Nation programme,
an initiative to transform the country through network technologies.
With the ambition of creating a national operating system of 100 million smart objects.
Unlike previous government-led technology initiatives,
which merely incorporated greater use of technology within a system tightly controlled by the government,
the Smart Nation seeks to replace parts of the government's planning functions with digital feedback loops altogether.
At the core of the programme is the Smart Nation Sensor Platform,
an integrated national sensor network that aims to make every lamppost a smart lamppost,
with a variety of sensors monitoring everything from temperature,
humidity,
water levels,
crowd patterns to traffic movements can be mounted.
As the culmination of over a decade of research and innovation carried out in collaboration with institutions such as MIT,
the platform will, upon completion, transform Singapore into what MIT researchers call a real-time city.
The two neighbourhoods selected to pilot the platform were Geylang and Little India,
both popular weekend gathering spots for the city-state's 1 million or so low-wage migrant workers,
coming mostly
from South Asia.
Significantly,
just about a year before the rollout of the programme,
The country's first riot in 40 years had taken place in Little India,
following the outbreak of an angry mob at the scene of a motor accident that killed an Indian construction worker.
In a public address made in the aftermath,
the Prime Minister conceded that the authorities were caught flat-footed by the riot due to insufficient CCTV coverage in the area.
As a result,
they had to turn to footage posted on social media,
captured by civilians. who,
as the Prime Minister added,
would in time be integrated into the National Sensor Network as mobile human sensors on the ground.
Since then,
critiques have largely sought to frame the Smart Nation programme as a tool of surveillance and racial profiling.
However,
proponents of the programme insist that the technologies being developed are designed not to collect individual data,
but to detect statistical irregularities.
As the senior civil servant, Peter Ho, explains,
in today's complex and dynamic environments,
governments cannot rely on established figures and categories of understanding to anticipate the future,
but must instead pay attention to weak signals that point towards emerging phenomena that are not yet fully understood.
And precisely because weak signals have no stable points of reference,
they cannot be detected through dumb systems that are designed to filter out the noise from the dataset. Based on a fixed
and rationalized set of rules.
Instead,

what is required are smart technologies that isolate the data generated by a data point to be continually re-bundled with other packets of data within the population to be analyzed for divergences from an ever-shifting norm.
Through this process,
the network is able to,
for example,
flag an individual as a security risk,
not based on identity markers like race or nationality.
But on something as mundane as their movements across the city,
or even the speed at which they move from one smart lamppost to another.
It is for this reason that I've always advised friends visiting Singapore to not move too quickly or too slowly in relation to other pedestrians on the streets,
just in case a smart lamppost flags you as a potential thief on the run,
or a very inefficient walker.
Much like how Carl Deutsch imagined
that a rewiring of neural signals could undo racial stereotypes.
Here,
the idiosyncratic connections made by a network trained on data that would otherwise be discarded as noise,
serve to dismantle an existing archive of representations in order for new and unexpected patterns of information to emerge.
It follows that if a network as intelligent as such does end up perpetuating existing social inequalities,
it is not because it is explicitly designed to reproduce a class hierarchy of figures,
like in the Colonial museum.
Instead,
as we shall see,
the intelligence of the network operates within a different order of representation and regime of power altogether,
one that implicates both the nation and the network,
the plan and the feedback loop,
the citizen and the data point.
